articles.headline: Lawyers Suing G.M. Over Defect Are Now Fighting Each Other
articles.snippet: The lawyer who exposed the ignition problem urged a judge to remove the three plaintiffs’ lawyers leading the litigation, accusing them of bungling a trial.
articles.abstract: The lawyer who exposed the ignition problem urged a judge to remove the three plaintiffs’ lawyers leading the litigation, accusing them of bungling a trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: The plaintiffs’ lawyers suing General Motors over its faulty ignition switch have been fighting to hold the carmaker accountable for the defect. But those lawyers are now fighting among themselves, threatening to throw the litigation against G.M. into disarray.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier

articles.headline: Ponzi Scheme in China Gained Credibility From State Media
articles.snippet: The police say Ding Ning’s Internet financing business, Ezubao, was a $7.6 billion Ponzi scheme and have arrested him and 20 others.
articles.abstract: The police say Ding Ning’s Internet financing business, Ezubao, was a $7.6 billion Ponzi scheme and have arrested him and 20 others.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — At every turn in his improbably rapid rise, Ding Ning, 34, went to great efforts to convey the image of strong government backing for his Internet financing business.
articles.byline: By Neil Gough

articles.headline: Why the Film Academy’s Diversity Push Is Tougher Than It Thinks
articles.snippet: The Motion Picture Academy wants to double its minority membership and achieve gender parity. A close look at its largest group, the actors branch, shows how far it has to go.
articles.abstract: The Motion Picture Academy wants to double its minority membership and achieve gender parity. A close look at its largest group, the actors branch, shows how far it has to go.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Roughly 87 percent are white. About 58 percent are male. As many as two-thirds are at least 60 years old.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Tips on Reducing Cable and Phone Bills From Ethically Ambiguous Experts
articles.snippet: When calling cable and phone providers to negotiate better deals, employees of BillFixers impersonate their clients. Whatever the ethics of this approach, their negotiating tactics have much to teach.
articles.abstract: When calling cable and phone providers to negotiate better deals, employees of BillFixers impersonate their clients. Whatever the ethics of this approach, their negotiating tactics have much to teach.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRENTWOOD, Tenn. — Cable companies and mobile phone service providers now offer so many deals, options, add-ons and doodads that the sheer number of potential pricing plans can boggle the mind. Chances are, you’re paying too much. Chances are, most everyone is.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: Syrian Forces Press Aleppo, Sending Thousands Fleeing
articles.snippet: The government’s gains have sent insurgents scrambling, led civilians to flee toward the border with Turkey and scuttled peace talks in Geneva.
articles.abstract: The government’s gains have sent insurgents scrambling, led civilians to flee toward the border with Turkey and scuttled peace talks in Geneva.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian government and allied forces pressed their most significant advance in months on Friday, sending insurgents scrambling and tens of thousands of civilians fleeing toward the border with Turkey.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard

articles.headline: Twitter Steps Up Efforts to Thwart Terrorists’ Tweets
articles.snippet: The company said it had suspended 125,000 accounts associated with extremism since mid-2015 and was accelerating its review of users suspected of spreading terrorism.
articles.abstract: The company said it had suspended 125,000 accounts associated with extremism since mid-2015 and was accelerating its review of users suspected of spreading terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Twitter has positioned itself as a “global town square” that is open to discourse from all. And for years, extremist groups like the Islamic State have taken advantage of that stance, using Twitter as a place to spread their messages.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Wildly Popular App Kik Offers Teenagers, and Predators, Anonymity
articles.snippet: Kik goes further than most widely used apps in shielding its users from view, often making it hard for law enforcement officials to know who is using it — or how.
articles.abstract: Kik goes further than most widely used apps in shielding its users from view, often making it hard for law enforcement officials to know who is using it — or how.
articles.lead_paragraph: The allegations are beyond chilling: two Virginia Tech freshmen charged with the premeditated kidnapping and killing of a 13-year-old girl who, authorities say, communicated with her murderer online.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Agencies Battle Over What Is ‘Top Secret’ in Hillary Clinton’s Emails
articles.snippet: At the center of the argument, officials said, is a “top secret” C.I.A. program that is anything but secret — its effort to kill suspected terrorists with drones.
articles.abstract: At the center of the argument, officials said, is a “top secret” C.I.A. program that is anything but secret — its effort to kill suspected terrorists with drones.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some of the nation’s intelligence agencies raised alarms last spring as the State Department began releasing emails from Hillary Clinton’s private server, saying that a number of the messages contained information that should be classified “top secret.”
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Campaign, Billed as Self-Funded, Risks Little of His Fortune
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s White House run blurs the line between campaigning and brand-building and complicates his claims that he is funding his own campaign.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s White House run blurs the line between campaigning and brand-building and complicates his claims that he is funding his own campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Donald J. Trump once boasted that he could someday be the only person to turn a profit running for president. He may be closer than anyone realizes.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Sarah Cohen

articles.headline: Faith in Agency Clouded Bernie Sanders’s V.A. Response
articles.snippet: Senator Bernie Sanders initially regarded complaints of trouble at the Department of Veterans Affairs as a play by conservatives to weaken one of the country’s largest social welfare institutions.
articles.abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders initially regarded complaints of trouble at the Department of Veterans Affairs as a play by conservatives to weaken one of the country’s largest social welfare institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: There were reports of secret waiting lists to hide long delays in care. Whistle-blowers said as many as 40 veterans had died waiting for appointments. And Congress was demanding answers.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder and Dave Philipps

articles.headline: Airlines Reap Record Profits, and Passengers Get Peanuts
articles.snippet: Despite the cost savings to airlines from plummeting oil prices, airfares on the biggest domestic carriers have hardly budged.
articles.abstract: Despite the cost savings to airlines from plummeting oil prices, airfares on the biggest domestic carriers have hardly budged.
articles.lead_paragraph: Helped by falling oil prices, airlines are reporting record profits, but for many passengers this sudden bonanza has meant little more than extra bags of free peanuts and pretzels.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Guantánamo Prisoner Sent Home to Morocco Remains in Legal Limbo
articles.snippet: Younis Shokuri feared being repatriated to Morocco, and his lawyers said they were assured there was a deal between the U.S. and Moroccan governments. Yet he remains in custody in his native country.
articles.abstract: Younis Shokuri feared being repatriated to Morocco, and his lawyers said they were assured there was a deal between the U.S. and Moroccan governments. Yet he remains in custody in his native country.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Younis Shokuri, a Moroccan detainee at the Guantánamo Bay prison, said he feared being repatriated to his native country. But the Moroccan government told the United States that it would probably release him without charges 72 hours after any transfer. So last September, Mr. Shokuri went home — reluctantly, but voluntarily.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Aida Alami

articles.headline: Emboldened by Protests, Black Lives Matter Activists Move From Street to Ballot
articles.snippet: Campaigns around the nation are betting on — and in some ways measuring — the strength of a young, energized electorate that is active in the movement for racial justice.
articles.abstract: Campaigns around the nation are betting on — and in some ways measuring — the strength of a young, energized electorate that is active in the movement for racial justice.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Within days of the fatal police shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., in August 2014, Maria Chappelle-Nadal huffed amid a crush of protesters, waving a cardboard cutout of the white governor’s face above her head.
articles.byline: By John Eligon

articles.headline: In Republican Debate, Rivals Jab at Marco Rubio to Try to Slow His Rise
articles.snippet: Mr. Rubio faced the fiercest attacks yet of the Republican race after his strong third-place finish in the Iowa caucuses.
articles.abstract: Mr. Rubio faced the fiercest attacks yet of the Republican race after his strong third-place finish in the Iowa caucuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Senator Marco Rubio of Florida was hammered as callow, ambitious and lacking in accomplishment during the Republican presidential debate here on Saturday night, as Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey led an all-out assault to try to halt Mr. Rubio’s growing momentum ahead of the critical New Hampshire primary on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Obama’s Lofty Plans on Gun Violence Amount to Little Action
articles.snippet: Few concrete actions have been put in motion to aggressively carry out the plans announced last month, despite the lofty expectations set by President Obama.
articles.abstract: Few concrete actions have been put in motion to aggressively carry out the plans announced last month, despite the lofty expectations set by President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The centerpiece of a plan for stemming gun violence that President Obama announced last month largely amounts to this: an updated web page and 10,000 pamphlets that federal agents will give out at gun shows.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Gloria Steinem and Madeleine Albright Rebuke Young Women Backing Bernie Sanders
articles.snippet: Ms. Steinem and Ms. Albright called on young women who favor Mr. Sanders over Hillary Clinton to essentially grow up and get with the program.
articles.abstract: Ms. Steinem and Ms. Albright called on young women who favor Mr. Sanders over Hillary Clinton to essentially grow up and get with the program.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — As Democrats consider Hillary Clinton’s candidacy for the second time, women are wrestling with a difficult question: whether they have an obligation to get behind someone who is closer than anyone has ever been to becoming the first female president.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Marco Rubio Comes Back Swinging After Difficult Debate
articles.snippet: The Florida senator, campaigning in New Hampshire, continued to hammer at President Obama’s leadership despite attacks by Chris Christie.
articles.abstract: The Florida senator, campaigning in New Hampshire, continued to hammer at President Obama’s leadership despite attacks by Chris Christie.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDONDERRY, N.H. — Senator Marco Rubio on Sunday confronted what may have been the most challenging moment of his presidential campaign as he tried to put to rest questions about his sure-footedness as a candidate and readiness for the presidency.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Built Up by Oil Boom, North Dakota Now Has an Emptier Feeling
articles.snippet: As the price of oil has skidded to $30 a barrel, new drilling has dried up, and the flood of wealth and workers is ebbing.
articles.abstract: As the price of oil has skidded to $30 a barrel, new drilling has dried up, and the flood of wealth and workers is ebbing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WILLISTON, N.D. — The “man camps” sprang up from the prairie, rows of trailers and modular steel boxes that housed thousands of workers chasing their fortunes in North Dakota’s oil fields. But these days, the man camps are missing something: men.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy

articles.headline: Tagore Translation Deemed Racy Is Pulled From Stores in China
articles.snippet: As the nation celebrates the 155th anniversary of the poet’s birth with a translation of his works, another tome, by Feng Teng, has caused a furor.
articles.abstract: As the nation celebrates the 155th anniversary of the poet’s birth with a translation of his works, another tome, by Feng Teng, has caused a furor.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Nearly 75 years after his death, Rabindranath Tagore, the Bengali poet and Nobel laureate, still has a huge following in Asia. Outside India and Bangladesh, perhaps nowhere is his legacy more alive than in China, where his works have been part of the middle-school curriculum for decades.
articles.byline: By Amy Qin

articles.headline: Step by Step on a Desperate Trek by Migrants Through Mexico
articles.snippet: Two days with 10 men who left Central America in early November to embark on an exhausting journey, made riskier by the Mexican authorities’ crackdown on migrants.
articles.abstract: Two days with 10 men who left Central America in early November to embark on an exhausting journey, made riskier by the Mexican authorities’ crackdown on migrants.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARRIAGA, Mexico — The police truck appeared suddenly, a glint of metal and glass. The migrants broke into a sprint, tripping over cracked pavement as an older woman sweeping her stoop urged them to hurry.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed

articles.headline: Unsafe Lead Levels in Tap Water Not Limited to Flint
articles.snippet: Contamination has turned up in scores of communities in recent years, and experts cite holes in the safety net of rules and procedures.
articles.abstract: Contamination has turned up in scores of communities in recent years, and experts cite holes in the safety net of rules and procedures.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Sebring, Ohio, routine laboratory tests last August found unsafe levels of lead in the town’s drinking water after workers stopped adding a chemical to keep lead water pipes from corroding. Five months passed before the city told pregnant women and children not to drink the water, and shut down taps and fountains in schools.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and John Schwartz

articles.headline: University of Phoenix Owner, Apollo Education Group, Will Be Taken Private
articles.snippet: The for-profit education provider would be taken private by a consortium of investors in a $1.1 billion deal.
articles.abstract: The for-profit education provider would be taken private by a consortium of investors in a $1.1 billion deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: The troubled for-profit education company that owns the giant University of Phoenix agreed on Monday to be bought for $1.1 billion by a group of investors that includes a private equity firm with close ties to the Obama administration.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Chad Bray

articles.headline: Facebook Loses a Battle in India Over Its Free Basics Program
articles.snippet: India has banned free mobile programs that allow Internet access only to certain services, a strategy employed by Facebook with its Free Basics project that was called antithetical to net neutrality.
articles.abstract: India has banned free mobile programs that allow Internet access only to certain services, a strategy employed by Facebook with its Free Basics project that was called antithetical to net neutrality.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, Mark Zuckerberg has had a grander vision than just connecting the more than one billion people who already use Facebook: He wants to connect the entire world.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Mike Isaac
